name.text: 16.2.1.2 Divergence condition for an infinite series

questiontext.text:
The divergence test

An almost obvious requirement that an infinite series should be convergent is that the individual terms in the series should get smaller and smaller. This leads to the following Key Point:

Key Point

The condition: \[ a_p \to 0 \qquad \mathrm{as} \; p \; \mathrm{increases} \quad \left(\text{mathematically:} \lim_{p \to \infty} a_p = 0\right)\] is a necessary condition for the convergence of the series \(\displaystyle{ \sum_{p=1}^{\infty} a_p}\) . 

It is not possible for an infinite series to be convergent unless this condition holds.


We need to be careful with the logic here. If a series converges then its terms tend to zero. If we observe that the terms of a series tend to zero then we cannot make any conclusion about the series. It might converge, or it might diverge (see the harmonic series).

If we reverse the logic, called taking the contrapositive, we have the following key point.


Key Point

Given the series \[\sum_{p=1}^\infty a_p\] we can negate the condition above \[ a_p \nrightarrow 0 \qquad \mathrm{as} \; p \; \mathrm{increases} \quad \left(\text{mathematically:} \lim_{p \to \infty} a_p \neq 0\text{ or }\lim_{p \to \infty} a_p\text{ does not exist.}\right) \] When this condition is satisfied we can conclusively say that the series is divergent. This is called the divergence test.

Remember that not all divergent series satisify the divergence test.
